study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticoccidial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects of Persea americana (avocado) fruit extract (PAFE) in mice infected with Eimeria papillata.
results_summary: PAFE at 500 mg/kg significantly reduced oocyst output (85.41%), decreased parasite stages, increased goblet cells, improved oxidative status (higher GSH, lower MDA and NO), and downregulated inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α, IFN-γ). The extract showed comparable efficacy to the reference drug amprolium.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice infected with E. papillata.
effective_dosage: 100, 300, and 500 mg/kg body weight (single oral dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new method using optical images and deep learning to detect adulterations in avocado oil.
results_summary: The study successfully classified ~95% of images of adulterated avocado oil samples using a residual neural network (ResNet34), demonstrating high accuracy in detecting adulterations with refined olive oil.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on oil samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a microbubble process in detaching Listeria monocytogenes from avocado surfaces.
results_summary: The study found that microbubble treatment for 10 minutes achieved a 1.65 log reduction of L. monocytogenes on avocado surfaces after 24 hours of drying. The method showed promise as an effective, economical, and environmentally friendly way to remove bacterial pathogens from fresh produce.
population_specificity: Avocado surfaces inoculated with L. monocytogenes (LCDC strain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether avocado oil could protect against lufenuron-induced reproductive toxicity, oxidative stress, and DNA damage in male rats.
results_summary: Avocado oil improved reproductive hormone levels, sperm parameters, antioxidant enzyme activity, and reduced histological and DNA damage caused by lufenuron, suggesting a protective role against testicular toxicity.
population_specificity: Mature male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming one large avocado daily for six months would reduce visceral adipose tissue volume and improve cardiometabolic risk factors in individuals with elevated waist circumference.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in visceral adipose tissue volume or hepatic fat fraction, and minimal effects on cardiometabolic risk factors, except for modest reductions in total and LDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: Free-living individuals (N=1008) with elevated waist circumference.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high degree of polymerization agave fructans (HDPAF) on anthracnose disease, defense-related enzyme activities, and quality attributes in postharvest avocado fruit.
results_summary: A 20% HDPAF solution reduced anthracnose severity (60%) and incidence (34%), increased defense-related enzyme activities, and slowed firmness and physiological weight loss without negatively affecting quality parameters like color, pH, total soluble solids, and titratable acidity.
population_specificity: Postharvest avocado fruit
study_duration: Not specified (measured effects at 0.5h and 24h post-treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prospective association between avocado consumption and incident hypertension in Mexican women.
results_summary: Frequent avocado consumption (5+ servings per week) was associated with a 17% decrease in hypertension incidence compared to non- or low consumers. The study found a statistically significant trend (Ptrend = 0.01) supporting this association.
population_specificity: Mexican women aged ≥25 years, free of hypertension, CVD, and cancer at baseline (n=67,383).
effective_dosage: 5+ servings per week (half an avocado per serving).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the economic and welfare impact of integrated pest and pollinator management (IPPM) on avocado production systems in Kenya and Tanzania.
results_summary: The study found that adopting IPPM could yield significant economic gains—US$ 66 million annually in Kenya and US$ 1.4 million in Tanzania—with high benefit-cost ratios (13:1 and 34:1, respectively). It also projected reductions in poverty by 10,464 people in Kenya and 1,255 in Tanzania annually.
population_specificity: Avocado producers and value chain actors in Kenya and Tanzania.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the baseline microbial population of the avocado carposphere and understand shifts in fungal community structure from harvest to ready-to-eat stages.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in fungal richness between postharvest stages, with a decline following fungicide treatment. Pathogenic genera were detected, but beneficial genera like Papiliotrema, Meyerozyma, and Aureobasidium dominated. Fungicide use reduced pathogenic fungi but also negatively affected beneficial species.
population_specificity: Avocado fruit (fructoplane and stem-end pulp)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant potential of avocado (Persea americana) seed extracts and their effects on oxidative stress and dyslipidemia in rats fed a high-fat, high-sucrose diet.
results_summary: The study found that the 1:1 avocado-garlic formulation (F(1:1)) showed strong antioxidant activity in vitro and significantly improved antioxidant markers, reduced lipid levels, and lowered blood glucose and body weight in rats.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fat, high-sucrose diet (HFHSD).
effective_dosage: 400 mg/kg body weight, administered once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether replacing carbohydrate energy with avocado energy for 12 weeks improves glucose homeostasis and cardiometabolic risk factors in overweight or obese adults with insulin resistance.
results_summary: Avocado intake led to a healthier dietary pattern with higher MUFA, PUFA, and fiber intake, and showed trends toward improved glucose control and reduced cardiometabolic risk biomarkers, including lower C-reactive protein. However, no significant changes in insulin sensitivity or body weight were observed.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (n=93; age 42±12 years; BMI 32.6±3.9 kg/m²) with insulin resistance.
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants were counseled to exchange avocado for carbohydrate foods in their usual diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardiac effects of avocado (Persea americana) consumption in horses, focusing on acetogenin-induced heart damage.
results_summary: The study found severe cardiac fibroplasia in horses that consumed avocado leaves and fruit, with immunohistochemical evidence of reduced cardiac troponin C expression. Acetogenins (persin and avocadene 1-acetate) were identified in avocado leaves and fruits, with higher concentrations in the pulp.
population_specificity: Horses (six on a farm, two died, one necropsied, four examined via electrocardiogram, echocardiogram, and serum Troponin 1).
effective_dosage: Not specified (horses fed themselves with leaves or mature fruit pulp and skin on the ground).
study_duration: Two-year study (duration of exposure not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether avocado intake improves anthropometric parameters (e.g., body weight, body composition) and metabolic health in individuals with excess body weight.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in body weight, BMI, body fat percentage, or visceral adipose tissue in the avocado group compared to the control group. Some potential benefits were noted in metabolic parameters, particularly lipid profile, but avocado did not promote weight loss or gain.
population_specificity: Individuals with excess body weight (657 participants across 8 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of soil additives (organic mulches, silica-based mineral mulch) and phosphite spraying on avocado plant growth and microbial responses when infested with Phytophthora cinnamomi.
results_summary: Phosphite and mineral mulch treatments reduced root damage in infested avocado plants. Bacterial diversity decreased in infested rhizospheres and root endospheres, with mineral mulch showing the greatest impact on community composition. Actinobacteria and Proteobacteria increased in abundance in Phytophthora-infested rhizospheres.
population_specificity: Avocado plants (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the polyphenol content, antioxidant activity, and α-amylase inhibitory potential of ethanolic extracts from avocado fruit and leaves for potential diabetes treatment.
results_summary: Avocado leaf extract had higher total phenolic content, while fruit extract showed stronger α-amylase inhibition (92.13% vs. 88.95% at 1000 μg/mL). Both extracts exhibited significant antioxidant activity, scavenging over 90% of DPPH radicals at high concentrations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 1000 μg/mL (single concentration tested for key outcomes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of four fungicidal products in reducing root necrosis and improving plant biomass in avocado seedlings infected with black root rot fungi.
results_summary: Fludioxonil, thiophanate-methyl + etridiazole, prochloraz, and prochloraz MnCl significantly reduced root necrosis and improved plant biomass in avocado seedlings infected with Calonectria ilicicola. Fludioxonil and prochloraz MnCl also reduced reisolation frequency of Dactylonectria macrodidyma, though symptoms were less severe with this fungus.
population_specificity: Avocado (Persea americana) seedlings in a greenhouse setting.
effective_dosage: Applied as pot drenches at 2 and 4 weeks after inoculation.
study_duration: Duration of the trial was longer for D. macrodidyma, but exact length not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an aqueous extract of Persea americana seeds (AEPAS) could serve as a therapeutic agent for diabetes by improving insulin sensitivity and regulating glycolipid metabolism in diabetic rats.
results_summary: AEPAS demonstrated significant reductions in diabetic markers (FBG, TG, LDL-c, IL-6, TNF-α, NF-ĸB) and improved insulin sensitivity, liver glycogen, and HDL-c levels. It also activated the PI3K/AkT pathway and inhibited β-cell death, suggesting potential antidiabetic effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with alloxan-induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study used an aqueous extract without detailed dosage information).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the composition and pharmacological activity of seven commercially available avocado/soybean unsaponifiable (ASU) products on human osteoarthritis chondrocytes.
results_summary: PIASCLEDINE-ExpASU® showed a unique composition and was the most effective in inhibiting pro-inflammatory factors (nitric oxide, IL-6, IL-8) and increasing aggrecan production, while other ASU products varied in their effects on MMP-3 and tocopherol content.
population_specificity: Human osteoarthritis chondrocytes cultured in alginate beads.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium hydroxide-modified avocado shells (NaOH-AS) as an adsorbent for removing crystal violet dye (CV) from wastewater.
results_summary: The NaOH-AS material achieved high adsorption efficiency (>96.9%) for CV dye at pH >8, with improved adsorption capacity (179.80 mg g-1) after NaOH treatment. The process followed pseudo-second-order kinetics and was governed by electrostatic interactions, demonstrating satisfactory reusability.
population_specificity: Wastewater contaminated with crystal violet dye.
effective_dosage: 1 M NaOH treatment for avocado shells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an extract of unripe avocados enriched in mannoheptulose (MH) could prevent obesity-related metabolic changes induced by a high-fat diet in mice.
results_summary: The study found that the avocado extract (HF + MH diet) completely protected mice against obesity-related metabolic changes, including increased body weight, body fat, blood lipids, and oxidative stress, while improving insulin sensitivity and physical performance, without affecting food intake. The extract also attenuated signaling in the mTOR pathway, suggesting potential metabolic benefits.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice starting at 16 weeks of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of PLA/FG/PLA multilayer films supplemented with almond shell extract and cellulose nanocrystals in preserving Hass avocados.
results_summary: The study found that the developed films demonstrated low oxygen permeability and solubility, good mechanical properties, and effectively preserved avocado pulp for 14 days at 4 °C, as indicated by low peroxide and anisidine values.
population_specificity: Hass avocados (food preservation context)
effective_dosage: 6 wt.% almond shell extract + 4.5 wt.% cellulose nanocrystals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of chloropicrin, biological control agents (B-Rus, Beta-Bak, Mity-Gro, Trichoderma), and fluazinam against Rosellinia necatrix in avocado plants.
results_summary: Trichoderma and B-Rus were as effective as fluazinam in inhibiting R. necatrix in vitro and suppressing white root rot symptoms when applied before pathogen inoculation. Fluazinam suppressed symptoms at early infection stages, while chloropicrin rendered the pathogen nonviable as a preplant treatment.
population_specificity: Avocado plants (Persea americana) infected with Rosellinia necatrix.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of autohydrolysis of avocado peel (AP) for recovering oligosaccharides and polyphenolics with bioactive properties for food and cosmetic applications.
results_summary: The study found that autohydrolysis at 150°C yielded high recovery of oligosaccharides (14.3 g/100 g AP) and antioxidant phenolics (3.48 g gallic acid equivalents/100 g AP). UHPLC-TOF MS identified 43 bioactive compounds, suggesting AP's potential for industrial use.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on avocado peel residues).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve understanding of the quality traits of avocado cv. Hass at the ready-to-eat stage, focusing on ripening effects under different temperatures and exogenous ethylene treatment.
results_summary: The study evaluated key qualitative traits (weight loss, dry matter, hardness, color) over 96 hours at two temperatures (+8°C and +17°C) and confirmed quality via sensory panel. Exogenous ethylene accelerated ripening, maintaining desirable attributes for ready-to-eat consumption.
population_specificity: Avocado cv. Hass fruits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of avocado virgin oil (AVO) on eggplant during different cooking methods, focusing on changes in functional compounds like phenols, fatty acids, and sterols.
results_summary: AVO maintained its phenolic content and fatty acid/sterol profiles after cooking, while eggplant gained antioxidant capacity and additional phenols. Cooking facilitated the transfer of beneficial lipophilic compounds from AVO to eggplant, enhancing its functional properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (food-based study, no human participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether avocado seed powder could mitigate cyclosporine A-induced nephrotoxicity while enhancing its immunosuppressive effects in rats.
results_summary: Avocado seed powder (5%) ameliorated CsA-induced nephrotoxicity by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and DNA damage, while also enhancing CsA's immunosuppressive effect.
population_specificity: Rats with CsA-induced nephrotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the GORE® VIABAHN® VBX covered stent in treating complex aortoiliac artery disease.
results_summary: The study found a 93.4% primary patency rate at 12 months and a 95.3% freedom from target lesion revascularization rate, indicating strong efficacy. Technical success was achieved in 92.6% of cases.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with aortoiliac disease (mean age 73.4, 77% male, 45% diabetic, 18% with end-stage renal dysfunction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an Avocado-based Mediterranean diet reduces LDL-C levels compared to a low-fat high-complex carbohydrate diet in patients with recent acute ischemic stroke.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that the Avocado-based diet would further reduce LDL-C levels at 3 months and be safe and feasible, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients within a month of being admitted with an ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of daily Hass avocado consumption on abdominal adiposity, insulin resistance, and glycemic outcomes in adults with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study found that daily avocado consumption altered abdominal adiposity distribution in females, reducing visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and the VAT-to-SAAT ratio, but did not improve peripheral insulin sensitivity or β-cell function. The control group showed greater reductions in subcutaneous abdominal adipose tissue (SAAT) and increases in the VAT-to-SAAT ratio compared to the avocado group.
population_specificity: 105 adults aged 25-45 years (61% female) with BMI ≥25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the inflammatory, immunomodulatory, cytotoxic, antioxidant, and antimicrobial properties of bioactive molecules in Mexican avocado seed.
results_summary: The study found that avocado fatty acids and seed oil exhibit beneficial effects on cardiovascular disease risk factors, antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, and potential antimicrobial, immunomodulatory, and cytotoxic activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of avocado/soy unsaponifiables (ASU) on serum antioxidant and oxidative stress markers in patients with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: ASU significantly reduced oxidative stress (measured by MDA levels) and improved antioxidant levels (TAC, GSH, SOD, CAT) in osteoarthritis patients compared to baseline and placebo. The effect was consistent regardless of treatment order.
population_specificity: 40 patients with osteoarthritis
study_duration: 3 months per treatment phase (total 6 months with cross-over)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of avocado consumption on the gastrointestinal microbiota and microbial metabolites, and assess relations between these factors and health markers.
results_summary: Daily avocado consumption increased gut microbial diversity, enriched beneficial bacteria, raised fecal fatty acids and short-chain fatty acids, and reduced bile acid concentrations. These changes suggest avocado positively affects digestive physiology and microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-45 with a BMI ≥ 25.0.
effective_dosage: 175 g/day for men, 140 g/day for women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ethanol extract from Persea americana (avocado) seeds on an experimental model of endometriosis in rats.
results_summary: The ethanol extract of avocado seeds reduced endometrial implant volume, lowered estradiol and progesterone levels, improved oxidative status, and positively affected ovarian follicle counts in rats with induced endometriosis.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with surgically induced endometriosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the cause of "tannin stain" symptoms in New Zealand 'Hass' avocado orchards and determine the pathogenic species of Colletotrichum fungi associated with the disease.
results_summary: The study identified eight Colletotrichum species, including three new records for New Zealand (C. fructicola, C. perseae, and C. siamense), as causative agents of "tannin stain" symptoms. Pathogenicity was confirmed through inoculation tests, fulfilling Koch's postulates, though the individual contributions of the new species to symptoms were not determined.
population_specificity: Commercial 'Hass' avocado orchards in mid-North and Tauranga, New Zealand.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on pathogen identification, not dosage).
study_duration: Fruit incubation period was 7 days post-inoculation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an avocado-like Fe3+/Fe2O3-based T1-T2 dual-mode MRI contrast agent with photothermal and drug delivery capabilities for cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that the developed material (CNMN) demonstrated suitable relaxation coefficients for MRI, strong photothermal properties, and effective delivery of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin (DOX), enabling high-efficacy chemo-photothermal combination therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effect of Arthrocen (containing avocado and soy extracts) in acetic acid-induced colitis in rats.
results_summary: Arthrocen reduced macroscopic and microscopic damage, decreased MPO and TNF-α activity, and suppressed pNF-κB expression, demonstrating anti-inflammatory effects via the NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with acetic acid-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Avocado Seed Glycosides (ASG) on diabetes-induced vascular damage compared to standard anti-diabetic and vascular drugs.
results_summary: ASG showed slight modulatory effects on glucose homeostasis but significantly normalized vascular damage markers (renin, angiotensin, VCAM-1, Lp-PLA2, Hcy, CnT, LDH, Crt-K, LDL-c, TG, TC, and HDL-c) in diabetic rats. Water intake remained altered despite treatment.
population_specificity: Rats with Diabetes-Induced Vascular Damage (DIVD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and characterize antagonist bacteria against Colletotrichum gloeosporioides to explore their potential as biological control agents for avocado anthracnose.
results_summary: Three bacterial isolates (A1, A2, A3) significantly reduced fungal growth, with Bacillus mycoides A1 showing the highest efficacy (75% reduction). Preventive treatment with B. mycoides A1 cell-free supernatant reduced anthracnose severity by 41.9% on avocado fruit.
population_specificity: Avocado rhizospheric soil samples from an orchard in Ocuituco, Morelos, Mexico.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of wood biochar on avocado growth, fruit production, and economic benefit in orchard soils.
results_summary: Biochar significantly improved avocado seedling growth, increased fruit yield (97% greater in 2018, 20% higher in 2019), and enhanced soil carbon, tree diameter, and height compared to the control. The economic analysis projected a net benefit of US$8581 per hectare over three years.
population_specificity: Avocado trees in orchard soils.
effective_dosage: Biochar applied at 0%, 5%, 10%, and 20% volume by volume basis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which avocado oil extract (DKB122) protects auditory cells from damage caused by neomycin, focusing on antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and autophagy-activating effects.
results_summary: DKB122 enhanced detoxification and antioxidant gene expression, reduced ROS levels, inhibited apoptosis, downregulated inflammatory genes, and increased autophagic flux, suggesting otoprotective effects.
population_specificity: HEI-OC1 cells (auditory cells) and THP-1 cells (immune cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how genetic differences influence blood lipid changes in response to daily avocado consumption compared to a control meal in adults with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: The study found no significant group-by-time effects on total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, or triglycerides over 12 weeks, but identified specific genetic interactions where avocado consumption led to lower total cholesterol in certain individuals.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-45 with overweight and obesity (n=115, 37% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine and characterize the primary antibacterial effects of avocado honey on Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli, focusing on membrane potential, integrity, and metabolic activity.
results_summary: Avocado honey induced physiological changes in S. aureus and E. coli, including membrane polarization disruption and metabolic activity impairment, with effects varying by concentration and honey variety. The antibacterial action was comparable to other tested honey types but depth of response differed.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a topical cream containing avocado oil and saffron extract for reducing facial wrinkles and improving skin rejuvenation.
results_summary: The cream showed stability over 6 months and improved wrinkle grading in 30% and 45% of participants after 6 and 12 weeks, respectively. It also significantly reduced nasolabial fold area and volume while increasing skin elasticity, with no reported allergic reactions or changes in skin hydration.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of daily avocado consumption on cognitive function and lutein status in adults with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: The treatment group showed improved serum lutein levels and accuracy in the Flanker task, but cognitive benefits were independent of lutein changes. No significant changes in macular pigment optical density (MPOD) or relationships between performance and lutein status were observed.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-45 with overweight or obesity (84 participants, 31 males).
effective_dosage: Daily meal with fresh Hass avocado (exact quantity not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the biological effects, chemical composition, pharmacotherapy, and applications of avocado-soybean unsaponifiables (ASU) in auto-immune, osteoarticular, and menopausal disorders, as well as discuss its safety and regulatory practices.
results_summary: The study found that ASU has potent anti-inflammatory effects and is effective as an adjuvant treatment for osteoarthritic pain, autoimmune diseases, and menopausal symptoms, improving mood and quality of life in postmenopausal women.
population_specificity: Individuals with osteoarthritis, autoimmune diseases, diffuse scleroderma, scleroderma-like states, and postmenopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and assess the nutritional and therapeutic properties of avocado and its bioactive compounds, focusing on its potential in disease prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The review highlights avocado's unique nutritional composition, antioxidant content, and potential benefits for cancer, microbial, inflammatory, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases, while cautioning against exaggerated "superfood" claims.
population_specificity: Not specified (general research review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming one avocado daily in a heart-healthy diet reduces circulating oxidized LDL (oxLDL) and related oxidative stress markers in adults with overweight or obesity and elevated LDL-C.
results_summary: The avocado diet significantly decreased oxLDL levels (-7.0 U/L, -8.8%) and increased plasma lutein concentration (68.7%), with these effects differing significantly from the moderate-fat and lower-fat diets. The reduction in oxLDL was correlated with a decrease in small, dense LDL particles.
population_specificity: 45 men and women, aged 21-70, with overweight or obesity and elevated LDL-C (25th-90th percentile).
study_duration: 5 weeks per diet (total intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a lipid-rich extract from avocado seed (LEAS) could inhibit Staphylococcus aureus internalization into bovine mammary epithelial cells (bMECs) and modulate the innate immune response.
results_summary: LEAS (1-200 ng/ml) reduced S. aureus internalization by 60-80%, increased NO production and IL-10 expression, and decreased TNF-α expression, likely by inhibiting MAPK p38 activation. LEAS showed no antimicrobial or cytotoxic effects.
population_specificity: Bovine mammary epithelial cells (bMECs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate four methods for quantifying Phytophthora cinnamomi root colonization in avocado seedlings to improve disease management strategies.
results_summary: Root plating and root-baiting-plating were the most effective methods for quantifying P. cinnamomi, showing significant correlations with inoculated zoospore concentrations and low variability. qPCR from roots was effective but had higher variability and false negatives, while qPCR from lemon leaf disks was the least effective.
population_specificity: Avocado seedlings inoculated with P. cinnamomi zoospores.
effective_dosage: Zoospore concentrations ranging from 10-1 to 1 × 10^5 zoospores/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of daily avocado consumption as part of a hypocaloric diet on weight loss, body composition, satiety, inflammation biomarkers, and intestinal microbiota composition.
results_summary: Both groups experienced significant weight loss and reductions in BMI, body fat, and visceral adipose tissue, with no significant differences between groups. The avocado group showed changes in serum HGF and gut microbiota composition, along with trends in reduced inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: 51 healthy overweight/obese women and men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of avocado as a nutraceutical compound in treating obesity and its comorbidities by examining its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The study found that avocado improves enzymatic activity, modulates obesity-related impairments in the anti-inflammatory system, and reverses harmful effects on blood lipids without reported side effects.
population_specificity: In vitro, animal, and human studies (general population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of avocado-soybean unsaponifiables (ASU) in treating symptoms of hip or knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: ASU significantly reduced pain and improved symptoms in knee OA but showed no significant effect in hip OA. Adverse events were similar between ASU and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Patients with hip or knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant potential of avocado by-products (peel, seed coat, and seeds) and their protective effects against oxidative stress in a Parkinson’s disease model.
results_summary: The study found that avocado peel extract, particularly from the Colinred variety, had high phenolic content and antioxidant capacity. It protected transgenic parkin Drosophila melanogaster from paraquat-induced oxidative stress, movement impairment, and lipid peroxidation.
population_specificity: Transgenic parkin Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) as a model for Parkinson’s disease.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of a diet supplement made from unripe avocado on glucose tolerance and cardiometabolic risk factors in nondiabetic adults with obesity.
results_summary: Daily consumption of unripe avocado extract did not significantly alter glucose tolerance or insulin sensitivity overall, but showed preliminary benefits in insulin AUC for a subgroup with elevated baseline postprandial insulin levels.
population_specificity: Nondiabetic adults with obesity (60 participants, 47 female, age 48 ± 13 years, BMI 34.0 ± 2.6 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of avocado seed biomass (in natural, chemically activated, and activated carbon forms) as an adsorbent for removing heavy metals (Chromium and Lead) from wastewater.
results_summary: Avocado seed biomass achieved 80% adsorption efficiency under specific conditions, with activated forms showing improved removal of Pb (II) and Cr (VI). The Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second order kinetic models best described the adsorption process.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 1.25 g NB for Cr (VI), 0.15 g NB for Pb (II), 0.15 g AB for Pb (II), 0.35 g AB for Cr (VI), 0.15 g AC for Pb (II), 0.7 g AC for Cr (VI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional and phytochemical properties of non-edible fruit seeds, including avocado, and their potential applications in food products and waste reduction.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that avocado seeds, like other non-edible fruit seeds, contain bioactive constituents with potential health benefits and functional properties, suggesting their use in food formulation and waste reduction. However, specific clinical outcomes or efficacy data for avocado seeds are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of non-edible fruit seeds)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-administration of avocado (as a fatty food) with albendazole improves the cure rate or egg reduction rate of hookworm infection in Ugandan school children.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in cure rate or egg reduction rate when albendazole was taken with avocado compared to without avocado. The efficacy of albendazole was not enhanced by avocado co-administration.
population_specificity: School children with hookworm infection in Mayuge district, Uganda.
effective_dosage: 200 grams of avocado eaten directly after medication.
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up at 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of avocado consumption on cardiometabolic risk factors in healthy adults, those with cardiovascular disease, or at increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: Avocado consumption showed a small but significant reduction in total cholesterol, particularly in hypercholesterolemic populations, but no significant effects on LDL-C, HDL-C, or triglycerides in normocholesterolemic populations. Body weight and composition were not negatively affected.
population_specificity: Adults who were healthy, had clinical cardiovascular disease, or were at increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low (3) vs. high (14) avocado allotment on biomarkers of NAFLD, oxidative stress, and NAFLD fibrosis score in Hispanic/Latino adults.
results_summary: The study investigated the impact of avocado intake on hepatic function biomarkers (GGT, hsCRP, and NAFLD fibrosis score), but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding the outcomes.
population_specificity: Hispanic/Latino adults with NAFLD.
effective_dosage: Low (3) vs. high (14) avocado allotment (exact frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of two levels of avocado allotment, combined with nutrition education, on the nutritional status of Hispanic/Latino families.
results_summary: The study examined changes in family energy and macro- and micronutrient intakes but did not report specific outcomes in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Hispanic/Latino families with at least three members aged ≥5 years, residing together, free of severe chronic disease, not on specific diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily oral consumption of avocado could reduce skin aging in healthy overweight women by assessing skin physical characteristics and resistance to UVB radiation.
results_summary: The study found that daily avocado consumption increased skin elasticity and firmness in the forehead but did not affect hydration, pigmentation, sebum, or UVB resistance. Changes in melanin and erythema were observed in both groups over time.
population_specificity: Healthy overweight women aged 27-73 years with Fitzpatrick skin type II-IV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop consensus definitions for core outcomes in infertility research to standardize reporting.
results_summary: Consensus definitions for core outcomes were successfully developed, and a standardized reporting approach was established. The study involved multiple stakeholders, including healthcare professionals and individuals with fertility problems.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals, researchers, and people with fertility problems from 11 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming one avocado per day for six months reduces visceral adiposity and improves cardiometabolic risk factors in individuals with increased waist circumference.
results_summary: The study suggests that avocado consumption may decrease visceral adiposity and improve satiety, potentially reducing overall energy intake, though final MRI results from 936 participants are pending full analysis.
population_specificity: 1008 participants (72% women, 53% Non-Hispanic White, mean age 50 years) with increased waist circumference and low baseline avocado consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop consensus definitions for core outcomes in infertility research to standardize reporting.
results_summary: The study successfully developed consensus definitions for all core infertility outcomes and proposed a standardized reporting approach, but did not specifically evaluate avocado's effects.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals, researchers, and individuals with fertility problems from 11 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate traditional endemic Mexican foods, including avocado, as functional agents to improve metabolic status in individuals with cardiometabolic risk phenotypes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that avocado, among other traditional foods, may serve as a functional agent to improve metabolic status in individuals with risk phenotypes like insulin resistance and dyslipidemia, though specific results for avocado are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with cardiometabolic risk phenotypes, including insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, overweight, obesity, and dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of avocatin B (AvoB), an avocado-derived compound, on glucose and lipid metabolism in diet-induced obesity models and assess its safety in humans.
results_summary: AvoB improved glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, and reduced mitochondrial reactive oxygen species in vitro. In humans, AvoB was well-tolerated with no dose-limiting toxicity at 50 mg or 200 mg daily for 60 days.
population_specificity: Mice with diet-induced obesity and healthy human participants.
effective_dosage: 50 mg or 200 mg per day for humans.
study_duration: 5 weeks in mice, 60 days in humans.
